```
#' Specify a secondary axis
#'
#' This function is used in conjunction with a position scale to create a
#' secondary axis, positioned opposite of the primary axis. All secondary
#' axes must be based on a one-to-one transformation of the primary axes.
#'
#' @param transform A formula or function of a strictly monotonic transformation
#'
#' @param trans `r lifecycle::badge("deprecated")`
#'
#' @param name The name of the secondary axis
#'
#' @param breaks One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no breaks
#'   - `waiver()` for the default breaks computed by the transformation object
#'   - A numeric vector of positions
#'   - A function that takes the limits as input and returns breaks as output
#'
#' @param labels One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no labels
#'   - `waiver()` for the default labels computed by the transformation object
#'   - A character vector giving labels (must be same length as `breaks`)
#'   - A function that takes the breaks as input and returns labels as output
#'
#' @param guide A position guide that will be used to render
#'   the axis on the plot. Usually this is [guide_axis()].
#'
#' @details
#' `sec_axis()` is used to create the specifications for a secondary axis.
#' Except for the `trans` argument any of the arguments can be set to
#' `derive()` which would result in the secondary axis inheriting the
#' settings from the primary axis.
#'
#' `dup_axis()` is provide as a shorthand for creating a secondary axis that
#' is a duplication of the primary axis, effectively mirroring the primary axis.
#'
#' As of v3.1, date and datetime scales have limited secondary axis capabilities.
#' Unlike other continuous scales, secondary axis transformations for date and datetime scales
#' must respect their primary POSIX data structure.
#' This means they may only be transformed via addition or subtraction, e.g.
#' `~ . + hms::hms(days = 8)`, or
#' `~ . - 8*60*60`. Nonlinear transformations will return an error.
#' To produce a time-since-event secondary axis in this context, users
#' may consider adapting secondary axis labels.
#'
#' @examples
#' p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(cyl, mpg)) +
#'   geom_point()
#'
#' # Create a simple secondary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10))
#'
#' # Inherit the name from the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous("Miles/gallon", sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10, name = derive()))
#'
#' # Duplicate the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = dup_axis())
#'
#' # You can pass in a formula as a shorthand
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = ~ .^2)
#'
#' # Secondary axes work for date and datetime scales too:
#' df <- data.frame(
#'   dx = seq(
#'     as.POSIXct("2012-02-29 12:00:00", tz = "UTC"),
#'     length.out = 10,
#'     by = "4 hour"
#'   ),
#'   price = seq(20, 200000, length.out = 10)
#'  )
#'
#' # This may useful for labelling different time scales in the same plot
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime(
#'     "Date",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d",
#'     date_breaks = "6 hour",
#'     sec.axis = dup_axis(
#'       name = "Time of Day",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' # or to transform axes for different timezones
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime("
#'     GMT",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d %I %p",
#'     sec.axis = sec_axis(
#'       ~ . + 8 * 3600,
#'       name = "GMT+8",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%b %d %I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' @export
sec_axis <- function(transform = NULL,
                     name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(),
                     guide = waiver(), trans = deprecated()) {
  if (lifecycle::is_present(trans)) {
    deprecate_soft0("3.5.0", "sec_axis(trans)", "sec_axis(transform)")
    transform <- trans
  }

  # sec_axis() historically accepted two-sided formula, so be permissive.
  if (length(transform) > 2) transform <- transform[c(1,3)]

  transform <- as_function(transform)
  ggproto(NULL, AxisSecondary,
    trans = transform,
    name = name,
    breaks = breaks,
    labels = labels,
    guide = guide
  )
}
#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
dup_axis <- function(transform = identity, name = derive(), breaks = derive(),
                     labels = derive(), guide = derive(), trans = deprecated()) {
  sec_axis(transform, trans = trans, name, breaks, labels, guide)
}

is.sec_axis <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "AxisSecondary")
}

set_sec_axis <- function(sec.axis, scale) {
  if (!is.waiver(sec.axis)) {
    if (scale$is_discrete()) {
      if (!identical(.subset2(sec.axis, "trans"), identity)) {
        cli::cli_abort("Discrete secondary axes must have the {.fn identity} transformation.")
      }
    }
    if (is.formula(sec.axis)) sec.axis <- sec_axis(sec.axis)
    if (!is.sec_axis(sec.axis)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Secondary axes must be specified using {.fn sec_axis}.")
    }
    scale$secondary.axis <- sec.axis
  }
  return(scale)
}

#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
derive <- function() {
  structure(list(), class = "derived")
}
is.derived <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "derived")
}
#' @rdname ggplot2-ggproto
#' @format NULL
#' @usage NULL
#' @export
AxisSecondary <- ggproto("AxisSecondary", NULL,
  trans = NULL,
  axis = NULL,
  name = waiver(),
  breaks = waiver(),
  labels = waiver(),

  # This determines the quality of the remapping from the secondary axis and
  # back to the primary axis i.e. the exactness of the placement of the
  # breakpoints of the secondary axis.
  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  # Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  transform_range = function(self, range) {
    self$trans(range)
  },

  mono_test = function(self, scale){
    range <- scale$range$range

    # Check if plot is empty
    if (is.null(range)) {
      return()
    }

    transformation <- scale$get_transformation()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Test for monotonicity
    if (!is_unique(sign(diff(full_range))))
      cli::cli_abort(
        "Transformation for secondary axes must be strictly monotonic."
      )
  },

  break_info = function(self, range, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) return()

    # Test for monotonicity on unexpanded range
    if (!scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$mono_test(scale)
      breaks <- self$breaks
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }

    # Get scale's original range before transformation
    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
)
```

```
#' is a duplication of the primary axis, effectively mirroring the primary axis.
#'
#' As of v3.1, date and datetime scales have limited secondary axis capabilities.
#' Unlike other continuous scales, secondary axis transformations for date and datetime scales
#' must respect their primary POSIX data structure.
#' This means they may only be transformed via addition or subtraction, e.g.
#' `~ . + hms::hms(days = 8)`, or
#' `~ . - 8*60*60`. Nonlinear transformations will return an error.
#' To produce a time-since-event secondary axis in this context, users
#' may consider adapting secondary axis labels.
#'
#' @examples
#' p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(cyl, mpg)) +
#'   geom_point()
#'
#' # Create a simple secondary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10))
#'
#' # Inherit the name from the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous("Miles/gallon", sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10, name = derive()))
#'
#' # Duplicate the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = dup_axis())
#'
#' # You can pass in a formula as a shorthand
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = ~ .^2)
#'
#' # Secondary axes work for date and datetime scales too:
#' df <- data.frame(
#'   dx = seq(
#'     as.POSIXct("2012-02-29 12:00:00", tz = "UTC"),
#'     length.out = 10,
#'     by = "4 hour"
#'   ),
#'   price = seq(20, 200000, length.out = 10)
#'  )
#'
#' # This may useful for labelling different time scales in the same plot
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime(
#'     "Date",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d",
#'     date_breaks = "6 hour",
#'     sec.axis = dup_axis(
#'       name = "Time of Day",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' # or to transform axes for different timezones
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime("
#'     GMT",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d %I %p",
#'     sec.axis = sec_axis(
#'       ~ . + 8 * 3600,
#'       name = "GMT+8",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%b %d %I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' @export
sec_axis <- function(transform = NULL,
                     name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(),
                     guide = waiver(), trans = deprecated()) {
  if (lifecycle::is_present(trans)) {
    deprecate_soft0("3.5.0", "sec_axis(trans)", "sec_axis(transform)")
    transform <- trans
  }

  # sec_axis() historically accepted two-sided formula, so be permissive.
  if (length(transform) > 2) transform <- transform[c(1,3)]

  transform <- as_function(transform)
  ggproto(NULL, AxisSecondary,
    trans = transform,
    name = name,
    breaks = breaks,
    labels = labels,
    guide = guide
  )
}

#'
#' @export
dup_axis <- function(transform = identity, name = derive(), breaks = derive(),
                     labels = derive(), guide = derive(), trans = deprecated()) {
  sec_axis(transform, trans = trans, name, breaks, labels, guide)
}

is.sec_axis <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "AxisSecondary")
}

set_sec_axis <- function(sec.axis, scale) {
  if (!is.waiver(sec.axis)) {
    if (scale$is_discrete()) {
      if (!identical(.subset2(sec.axis, "trans"), identity)) {
        cli::cli_abort("Discrete secondary axes must have the {.fn identity} transformation.")
      }
    }
    if (is.formula(sec.axis)) sec.axis <- sec_axis(sec.axis)
    if (!is.sec_axis(sec.axis)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Secondary axes must be specified using {.fn sec_axis}.")
    }
    scale$secondary.axis <- sec.axis
  }
  return(scale)
}

#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
derive <- function() {
  structure(list(), class = "derived")
}
is.derived <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "derived")
}
#' @rdname ggplot2-ggproto
#' @format NULL
#' @usage NULL
#' @export
AxisSecondary <- ggproto("AxisSecondary", NULL,
  trans = NULL,
  axis = NULL,
  name = waiver(),
  breaks = waiver(),
  labels = waiver(),

  # This determines the quality of the remapping from the secondary axis and
  # back to the primary axis i.e. the exactness of the placement of the
  # breakpoints of the secondary axis.
  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  # Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  transform_range = function(self, range) {
    self$trans(range)
  },

  mono_test = function(self, scale){
    range <- scale$range$range

    # Check if plot is empty
    if (is.null(range)) {
      return()
    }

    transformation <- scale$get_transformation()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Test for monotonicity
    if (!is_unique(sign(diff(full_range))))
      cli::cli_abort(
        "Transformation for secondary axes must be strictly monotonic."
      )
  },

  break_info = function(self, range, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) return()

    # Test for monotonicity on unexpanded range
    if (!scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$mono_test(scale)
      breaks <- self$breaks
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }

    # Get scale's original range before transformation
    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
)
```

[Submission]: Looking at the code, I see that secondary axes for discrete scales need better handling of named breaks. Currently, when a discrete scale has named breaks, those names aren't being properly used as labels on the secondary axis. Let me propose some changes to fix this.

Here's my suggested modification:

```r
#' @rdname ggplot2-ggproto
#' @format NULL
#' @usage NULL
#' @export
AxisSecondary <- ggproto("AxisSecondary", NULL,
  trans = NULL,
  axis = NULL,
  name = waiver(),
  breaks = waiver(),
  labels = waiver(),

  # This determines the quality of the remapping from the secondary axis and
  # back to the primary axis i.e. the exactness of the placement of the
  # breakpoints of the secondary axis.
  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  # Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels) || is.waiver(self$labels)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete() && !is.null(names(self$breaks))) {
        # For discrete scales with named breaks, use the names as labels
        self$labels <- names(self$breaks)
      } else {
        self$labels <- scale$labels
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  # ... [rest of the code remains unchanged]
)
```

The key change is in the `init` function, where I've modified the labels handling. When the labels are derived or using the default waiver, and we have a discrete scale with named breaks, we now use those names as the labels instead.

This will ensure that discrete scales with named breaks will properly display those names as labels on the secondary axis by default, making the behavior more intuitive and consistent with how named breaks typically work in ggplot2.
***
[Criterion]: ```
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } 
```

...should be changed to:

```
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- setNames(scale$get_breaks())
      } 
```

and, later, on:

```
    else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }
```

can be changed to:

```
    else {
      breaks <- setNames(scale$map(self$breaks), names(self$breaks))
    }
```

That's all that's needed, but both changes are needed.

```
#' Specify a secondary axis
#'
#' This function is used in conjunction with a position scale to create a
#' secondary axis, positioned opposite of the primary axis. All secondary
#' axes must be based on a one-to-one transformation of the primary axes.
#'
#' @param transform A formula or function of a strictly monotonic transformation
#'
#' @param trans `r lifecycle::badge("deprecated")`
#'
#' @param name The name of the secondary axis
#'
#' @param breaks One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no breaks
#'   - `waiver()` for the default breaks computed by the transformation object
#'   - A numeric vector of positions
#'   - A function that takes the limits as input and returns breaks as output
#'
#' @param labels One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no labels
#'   - `waiver()` for the default labels computed by the transformation object
#'   - A character vector giving labels (must be same length as `breaks`)
#'   - A function that takes the breaks as input and returns labels as output
#'
#' @param guide A position guide that will be used to render
#'   the axis on the plot. Usually this is [guide_axis()].
#'
#' @details
#' `sec_axis()` is used to create the specifications for a secondary axis.
#' Except for the `trans` argument any of the arguments can be set to
#' `derive()` which would result in the secondary axis inheriting the
#' settings from the primary axis.
#'
#' `dup_axis()` is provide as a shorthand for creating a secondary axis that
#' is a duplication of the primary axis, effectively mirroring the primary axis.
#'
#' As of v3.1, date and datetime scales have limited secondary axis capabilities.
#' Unlike other continuous scales, secondary axis transformations for date and datetime scales
#' must respect their primary POSIX data structure.
#' This means they may only be transformed via addition or subtraction, e.g.
#' `~ . + hms::hms(days = 8)`, or
#' `~ . - 8*60*60`. Nonlinear transformations will return an error.
#' To produce a time-since-event secondary axis in this context, users
#' may consider adapting secondary axis labels.
#'
#' @examples
#' p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(cyl, mpg)) +
#'   geom_point()
#'
#' # Create a simple secondary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10))
#'
#' # Inherit the name from the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous("Miles/gallon", sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10, name = derive()))
#'
#' # Duplicate the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = dup_axis())
#'
#' # You can pass in a formula as a shorthand
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = ~ .^2)
#'
#' # Secondary axes work for date and datetime scales too:
#' df <- data.frame(
#'   dx = seq(
#'     as.POSIXct("2012-02-29 12:00:00", tz = "UTC"),
#'     length.out = 10,
#'     by = "4 hour"
#'   ),
#'   price = seq(20, 200000, length.out = 10)
#'  )
#'
#' # This may useful for labelling different time scales in the same plot
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime(
#'     "Date",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d",
#'     date_breaks = "6 hour",
#'     sec.axis = dup_axis(
#'       name = "Time of Day",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' # or to transform axes for different timezones
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime("
#'     GMT",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d %I %p",
#'     sec.axis = sec_axis(
#'       ~ . + 8 * 3600,
#'       name = "GMT+8",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%b %d %I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' @export
sec_axis <- function(transform = NULL,
                     name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(),
                     guide = waiver(), trans = deprecated()) {
  if (lifecycle::is_present(trans)) {
    deprecate_soft0("3.5.0", "sec_axis(trans)", "sec_axis(transform)")
    transform <- trans
  }

  # sec_axis() historically accepted two-sided formula, so be permissive.
  if (length(transform) > 2) transform <- transform[c(1,3)]

  transform <- as_function(transform)
  ggproto(NULL, AxisSecondary,
    trans = transform,
    name = name,
    breaks = breaks,
    labels = labels,
    guide = guide
  )
}
#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
dup_axis <- function(transform = identity, name = derive(), breaks = derive(),
                     labels = derive(), guide = derive(), trans = deprecated()) {
  sec_axis(transform, trans = trans, name, breaks, labels, guide)
}

is.sec_axis <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "AxisSecondary")
}

set_sec_axis <- function(sec.axis, scale) {
  if (!is.waiver(sec.axis)) {
    if (scale$is_discrete()) {
      if (!identical(.subset2(sec.axis, "trans"), identity)) {
        cli::cli_abort("Discrete secondary axes must have the {.fn identity} transformation.")
      }
    }
    if (is.formula(sec.axis)) sec.axis <- sec_axis(sec.axis)
    if (!is.sec_axis(sec.axis)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Secondary axes must be specified using {.fn sec_axis}.")
    }
    scale$secondary.axis <- sec.axis
  }
  return(scale)
}

#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
derive <- function() {
  structure(list(), class = "derived")
}
is.derived <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "derived")
}
#' @rdname ggplot2-ggproto
#' @format NULL
#' @usage NULL
#' @export
AxisSecondary <- ggproto("AxisSecondary", NULL,
  trans = NULL,
  axis = NULL,
  name = waiver(),
  breaks = waiver(),
  labels = waiver(),

  # This determines the quality of the remapping from the secondary axis and
  # back to the primary axis i.e. the exactness of the placement of the
  # breakpoints of the secondary axis.
  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  # Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  transform_range = function(self, range) {
    self$trans(range)
  },

  mono_test = function(self, scale){
    range <- scale$range$range

    # Check if plot is empty
    if (is.null(range)) {
      return()
    }

    transformation <- scale$get_transformation()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Test for monotonicity
    if (!is_unique(sign(diff(full_range))))
      cli::cli_abort(
        "Transformation for secondary axes must be strictly monotonic."
      )
  },

  break_info = function(self, range, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) return()

    # Test for monotonicity on unexpanded range
    if (!scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$mono_test(scale)
      breaks <- self$breaks
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }

    # Get scale's original range before transformation
    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
)
```

Please propose edits so that, when discrete breaks have names, they'll be used as labels by default.

```
#'     as.POSIXct("2012-02-29 12:00:00", tz = "UTC"),
#'     length.out = 10,
#'     by = "4 hour"
#'   ),
#'   price = seq(20, 200000, length.out = 10)
#'  )
#'
#' # This may useful for labelling different time scales in the same plot
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime(
#'     "Date",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d",
#'     date_breaks = "6 hour",
#'     sec.axis = dup_axis(
#'       name = "Time of Day",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' # or to transform axes for different timezones
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime("
#'     GMT",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d %I %p",
#'     sec.axis = sec_axis(
#'       ~ . + 8 * 3600,
#'       name = "GMT+8",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%b %d %I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' @export
sec_axis <- function(transform = NULL,
                     name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(),
                     guide = waiver(), trans = deprecated()) {
  if (lifecycle::is_present(trans)) {
    deprecate_soft0("3.5.0", "sec_axis(trans)", "sec_axis(transform)")
    transform <- trans
  }

  # sec_axis() historically accepted two-sided formula, so be permissive.
  if (length(transform) > 2) transform <- transform[c(1,3)]

  transform <- as_function(transform)
  ggproto(NULL, AxisSecondary,
    trans = transform,
    name = name,
    breaks = breaks,
    labels = labels,
    guide = guide
  )
}
#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
dup_axis <- function(transform = identity, name = derive(), breaks = derive(),
                     labels = derive(), guide = derive(), trans = deprecated()) {
  sec_axis(transform, trans = trans, name, breaks, labels, guide)
}

is.sec_axis <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "AxisSecondary")
}

set_sec_axis <- function(sec.axis, scale) {
  if (!is.waiver(sec.axis)) {
    if (scale$is_discrete()) {
      if (!identical(.subset2(sec.axis, "trans"), identity)) {
        cli::cli_abort("Discrete secondary axes must have the {.fn identity} transformation.")
      }
    }
    if (is.formula(sec.axis)) sec.axis <- sec_axis(sec.axis)
    if (!is.sec_axis(sec.axis)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Secondary axes must be specified using {.fn sec_axis}.")
    }
    scale$secondary.axis <- sec.axis
  }
  return(scale)
}

#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
derive <- function() {
  structure(list(), class = "derived")
}
is.derived <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "derived")
}
#' @rdname ggplot2-ggproto
#' @format NULL
#' @usage NULL
#' @export
AxisSecondary <- ggproto("AxisSecondary", NULL,
  trans = NULL,
  axis = NULL,
  name = waiver(),
  breaks = waiver(),
  labels = waiver(),

  # This determines the quality of the remapping from the secondary axis and
  # back to the primary axis i.e. the exactness of the placement of the
  # breakpoints of the secondary axis.
  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  # Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  transform_range = function(self, range) {
    self$trans(range)
  },

  mono_test = function(self, scale){
    range <- scale$range$range

    # Check if plot is empty
    if (is.null(range)) {
      return()
    }

    transformation <- scale$get_transformation()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Test for monotonicity
    if (!is_unique(sign(diff(full_range))))
      cli::cli_abort(
        "Transformation for secondary axes must be strictly monotonic."
      )
  },

  break_info = function(self, range, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) return()

    # Test for monotonicity on unexpanded range
    if (!scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$mono_test(scale)
      breaks <- self$breaks
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }

    # Get scale's original range before transformation
    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
)
```

```
#' Specify a secondary axis
#'
#' This function is used in conjunction with a position scale to create a
#' secondary axis, positioned opposite of the primary axis. All secondary
#' axes must be based on a one-to-one transformation of the primary axes.
#'
#' @param transform A formula or function of a strictly monotonic transformation
#'
#' @param trans `r lifecycle::badge("deprecated")`
#'
#' @param name The name of the secondary axis
#'
#' @param breaks One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no breaks
#'   - `waiver()` for the default breaks computed by the transformation object
#'   - A numeric vector of positions
#'   - A function that takes the limits as input and returns breaks as output
#'
#' @param labels One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no labels
#'   - `waiver()` for the default labels computed by the transformation object
#'   - A character vector giving labels (must be same length as `breaks`)
#'   - A function that takes the breaks as input and returns labels as output
#'
#' @param guide A position guide that will be used to render
#'   the axis on the plot. Usually this is [guide_axis()].
#'
#' @details
#' `sec_axis()` is used to create the specifications for a secondary axis.
#' Except for the `trans` argument any of the arguments can be set to
#' `derive()` which would result in the secondary axis inheriting the
#' settings from the primary axis.
#'
#' `dup_axis()` is provide as a shorthand for creating a secondary axis that
#' is a duplication of the primary axis, effectively mirroring the primary axis.
#'
#' As of v3.1, date and datetime scales have limited secondary axis capabilities.
#' Unlike other continuous scales, secondary axis transformations for date and datetime scales
#' must respect their primary POSIX data structure.
#' This means they may only be transformed via addition or subtraction, e.g.
#' `~ . + hms::hms(days = 8)`, or
#' `~ . - 8*60*60`. Nonlinear transformations will return an error.
#' To produce a time-since-event secondary axis in this context, users
#' may consider adapting secondary axis labels.
#'
#' @examples
#' p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(cyl, mpg)) +
#'   geom_point()
#'
#' # Create a simple secondary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10))
#'
#' # Inherit the name from the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous("Miles/gallon", sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10, name = derive()))
#'
#' # Duplicate the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = dup_axis())
#'
#' # You can pass in a formula as a shorthand
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = ~ .^2)
#'
#' # Secondary axes work for date and datetime scales too:
#' df <- data.frame(
#'   dx = seq(
#'     as.POSIXct("2012-02-29 12:00:00", tz = "UTC"),
#'     length.out = 10,
#'     by = "4 hour"
#'   ),
#'   price = seq(20, 200000, length.out = 10)
#'  )
#'
#' # This may useful for labelling different time scales in the same plot
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime(
#'     "Date",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d",
#'     date_breaks = "6 hour",
#'     sec.axis = dup_axis(
#'       name = "Time of Day",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' # or to transform axes for different timezones
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime("
#'     GMT",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d %I %p",
#'     sec.axis = sec_axis(
#'       ~ . + 8 * 3600,
#'       name = "GMT+8",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%b %d %I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' @export
sec_axis <- function(transform = NULL,
                     name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(),
                     guide = waiver(), trans = deprecated()) {
  if (lifecycle::is_present(trans)) {
    deprecate_soft0("3.5.0", "sec_axis(trans)", "sec_axis(transform)")
    transform <- trans
  }

  # sec_axis() historically accepted two-sided formula, so be permissive.
  if (length(transform) > 2) transform <- transform[c(1,3)]

  transform <- as_function(transform)
  ggproto(NULL, AxisSecondary,
    trans = transform,
    name = name,
    breaks = breaks,
    labels = labels,
    guide = guide
  )
}
```

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.
samples.target:
There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.

content.text:
I'll write tidyverse code to find the tailnum with the highest proportion of NA arr_delay values among planes that have flown at least 100 flights.

```r
flights %>%
  # Group by tailnum
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  # Calculate summary statistics for each plane
  summarize(
    total_flights = n(),
    na_arr_delays = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    na_proportion = na_arr_delays / total_flights
  ) %>%
  # Filter to include only planes with at least 100 flights
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%
  # Sort by the proportion of NA arr_delays in descending order
  arrange(desc(na_proportion)) %>%
  # Take the top result
  slice(1) %>%
  # Select just the tailnum
  select(tailnum)
```

This code:
1. Groups the flights data by tailnum
2. Calculates for each plane:
   - The total number of flights
   - The number of flights with NA arr_delay values
   - The proportion of flights with NA arr_delay values
3. Filters to include only planes that have flown at least 100 flights
4. Sorts by the proportion of NA arr_delay values in descending order
5. Takes the top result (the plane with the highest proportion)
6. Returns just the tailnum of that plane

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.

content.text:
I'll write tidyverse code to find the tailnum with the highest proportion of NA arr_delay values among planes that have flown at least 100 flights.

```r
flights %>%
  # Group by tailnum
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  # Calculate summary statistics for each plane
  summarize(
    total_flights = n(),
    na_arr_delays = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    na_proportion = na_arr_delays / total_flights
  ) %>%
  # Filter to include only planes with at least 100 flights
  filter(total_flights >= 100) %>%
  # Sort by the proportion of NA arr_delays in descending order
  arrange(desc(na_proportion)) %>%
  # Take the top result
  slice(1) %>%
  # Select just the tailnum
  select(tailnum)
```

This code:
1. Groups the flights data by tailnum
2. Calculates for each plane:
   - The total number of flights
   - The number of flights with NA arr_delay values
   - The proportion of flights with NA arr_delay values
3. Filters to include only planes that have flown at least 100 flights
4. Sorts by the proportion of NA arr_delay values in descending order
5. Takes the top result (the plane with the highest proportion)
6. Returns just the tailnum of that plane

events.target:
There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.

I get an error using `.by` inside `mutate()`

```
Error in `mutate()`:
 In argument: `by = c(id, date)`.
Caused by error:
! `by` must be size 2909492 or 1, not 5818984.
```

How do I fix it?

content.text:
# Error in `mutate()` with `.by` Argument

You're encountering this error because you're not using the `.by` parameter correctly in your `mutate()` function. The error indicates that your `by` vector has 5,818,984 elements, but it needs to match the number of rows in your data (2,909,492) or be a single value.

## Common Mistakes and Solutions

1. **Using `by =` instead of `.by =`**
   ```r
   # Incorrect
   df %>% mutate(new_col = mean(value), by = c(id, date))
   
   # Correct
   df %>% mutate(new_col = mean(value), .by = c(id, date))
   ```

2. **Not using `c()` properly**
   ```r
   # Incorrect - this creates a vector of all id and date values
   df %>% mutate(new_col = mean(value), .by = c(id, date))
   
   # Correct - this specifies grouping variables as column names
   df %>% mutate(new_col = mean(value), .by = c("id", "date"))
   # OR
   df %>% mutate(new_col = mean(value), .by = list(id, date))
   ```

## Recommended Approach

```r
# If your columns are unquoted
df %>% 
  mutate(new_col = mean(value), .by = list(id, date))

# Or with quoted column names
df %>% 
  mutate(new_col = mean(value), .by = c("id", "date"))
```

The error suggests you're either mixing up the `.by` parameter syntax or inadvertently creating a vector of all values instead of specifying column names.

You're encountering this error because you're not using the `.by` parameter correctly in your `mutate()` function. The error indicates that your `by` vector has 5,818,984 elements, but it needs to match the number of rows in your data (2,909,492) or be a single value.

## Common Mistakes and Solutions

1. **Using `by =` instead of `.by =`**
   ```r
   # Incorrect
   df %>% mutate(new_col = mean(value), by = c(id, date))
   
   # Correct
   df %>% mutate(new_col = mean(value), .by = c(id, date))
   ```

2. **Not using `c()` properly**
   ```r
   # Incorrect - this creates a vector of all id and date values
   df %>% mutate(new_col = mean(value), .by = c(id, date))
   
   # Correct - this specifies grouping variables as column names
   df %>% mutate(new_col = mean(value), .by = c("id", "date"))
   # OR
   df %>% mutate(new_col = mean(value), .by = list(id, date))
   ```

## Recommended Approach

```r
# If your columns are unquoted
df %>% 
  mutate(new_col = mean(value), .by = list(id, date))

# Or with quoted column names
df %>% 
  mutate(new_col = mean(value), .by = c("id", "date"))
```

The error suggests you're either mixing up the `.by` parameter syntax or inadvertently creating a vector of all values instead of specifying column names.

samples.input:
Add a `name` argument after `dataset` that defaults to the name of the `dataset` object in the calling env.

```
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    # TODO: maybe it doesn't need to be associated with a dir at all?
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {
  check_dataset(dataset)

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

  res <-
    structure(
      dataset,
      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  attr(res, "dir") <- dir

  res
}
```

Store it as a `name` attribute in `res`.

e.g. in:

```
x <- task_create(dataset = eval)
```

`attr(x, "name)` would be `"eval"`.
samples.target:
```
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    # TODO: maybe it doesn't need to be associated with a dir at all?
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {
  force(name)
  check_dataset(dataset)

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

  res <-
    structure(
      dataset,
      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  attr(res, "name") <- name
  attr(res, "dir") <- dir

  res
}
```

Notably:

* `name` should default to `deparse(substitute(dataset))` or something similar
* `name` needs be `force()`d, or somehow evaluated, before `check_dataset(dataset)` so that the substitution works correctly.
* At some point, the `name` attribute is set to the value.
* The rest of the function should be unaffected, e.g. no comments added to code that existed already.

I'll modify the `task_create` function to add a `name` argument that defaults to the name of the `dataset` object in the calling environment, and store it as a `name` attribute in the result.

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    # TODO: maybe it doesn't need to be associated with a dir at all?
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {
  check_dataset(dataset)

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

  res <-
    structure(
      dataset,
      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  attr(res, "dir") <- dir
  attr(res, "name") <- name

  res
}
```

This implementation:

1. Adds the `name` parameter with a default value from `deparse(substitute(dataset))`, which captures the variable name of the dataset argument in the calling environment
2. Sets this value as the "name" attribute on the result object

Now when you call `x <- task_create(dataset = eval)`, `attr(x, "name")` will return `"eval"`.

```r
      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  attr(res, "dir") <- dir

  res
}
```

Store it as a `name` attribute in `res`.

e.g. in:

```
x <- task_create(dataset = eval)
```

`attr(x, "name)` would be `"eval"`.

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    # TODO: maybe it doesn't need to be associated with a dir at all?
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {
```
```
  force(name)
  check_dataset(dataset)

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

  res <-
    structure(

}
```

Notably:

* `name` should default to `deparse(substitute(dataset))` or something similar
* `name` needs be `force()`d, or somehow evaluated, before `check_dataset(dataset)` so that the substitution works correctly.
* At some point, the `name` attribute is set to the value.
* The rest of the function should be unaffected, e.g. no comments added to code that existed already.

messages.content: How do I jitter points with ggplot2 only with respect to the x axis, leaving the y values unchanged?

content.text:
# Jittering Points on X-Axis Only in ggplot2

To jitter points only along the x-axis in ggplot2 while leaving the y values unchanged, you can use `position_jitterdodge()` or `position_jitter()` with specific parameters.

## Option 1: Using position_jitter()

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.1, height = 0))
```

The key is setting:
- `width` to your desired jitter amount (e.g., 0.1)
- `height = 0` to prevent any jittering on the y-axis

## Option 2: Using position_jitterdodge()

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitterdodge(jitter.width = 0.1, jitter.height = 0))
```

## Complete Example

```r
library(ggplot2)

# Sample data
set.seed(123)
data <- data.frame(
  category = rep(c("A", "B", "C"), each = 10),
  value = rnorm(30)
)

# Plot with x-axis jitter only
ggplot(data, aes(x = category, y = value)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0))
```

You can adjust the `width` parameter to control how much horizontal jittering you want.

The key is setting:
- `width` to your desired jitter amount (e.g., 0.1)
- `height = 0` to prevent any jittering on the y-axis

## Option 2: Using position_jitterdodge()

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = x_variable, y = y_variable)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitterdodge(jitter.width = 0.1, jitter.height = 0))
```

## Complete Example

```r
library(ggplot2)

# Sample data
set.seed(123)
data <- data.frame(
  category = rep(c("A", "B", "C"), each = 10),
  value = rnorm(30)
)

# Plot with x-axis jitter only
ggplot(data, aes(x = category, y = value)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0))
```

You can adjust the `width` parameter to control how much horizontal jittering you want.

samples.input:
I have some code

```
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
...
}
```

I'd like the default name to be the symbol referring to the dataset, e.g. in

```
simple_addition <- tibble(
  input = c("What's 2+2?", "What's 2+3?"),
  target = c("4", "5")
)

tsk <- 
  task_create(
    dataset = simple_addition
  )
```

...the name would be "simple_addition". Instead, it's substituted to `structure(list(input = c("What's 2+2?", "What's 2+3?"), target = c("4", , "5"), id = 1:2), row.names = c(NA, -2L), class = c("tbl_df", , and "tbl", "data.frame"))`. How can I fix that?
samples.target: The `name` default is evaluated lazily, and something else results in `dataset` being evaluated before `name` is. `name` must be evaluated early in the function, e.g. using `force(name)`.

content.text:
# Fixing the Default Name in `task_create()`

The issue is that `deparse(substitute(dataset))` evaluates after the argument `dataset` has already been evaluated. At that point, `substitute(dataset)` returns the actual tibble object, which when deparsed gives you that long string representation.

## Solution

You need to capture the unevaluated expression before the argument is evaluated. Here are two approaches:

### Option 1: Using quasiquotation (recommended)

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
    # Capture the expression before evaluation
    dataset_expr <- substitute(dataset)
    
    # If name is NULL, use the deparsed expression
    if (is.null(name)) {
        name <- deparse(dataset_expr)
    }
    
    # Rest of your function
    # ...
}
```

### Option 2: Using default missing argument

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name,
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
    # Capture the expression
    dataset_expr <- substitute(dataset)
    
    # If name is missing, use the deparsed expression
    if (missing(name)) {
        name <- deparse(dataset_expr)
    }
    
    # Rest of your function
    # ...
}
```

Both approaches will give you "simple_addition" as the name when you call `task_create(simple_addition)`.

The key difference is that with Option 1, users can explicitly pass `NULL` to get the automatic naming, while Option 2 requires the argument to be completely missing to trigger the automatic naming.

I need to evaluate whether the submission correctly addresses the issue with the `name` default being evaluated lazily, and whether it properly handles the fact that `dataset` is being evaluated before `name`.

The submission provides two approaches, but neither directly addresses the lazy evaluation issue as specified in the criterion. Let's analyze:

The core problem is that by the time `name = deparse(substitute(dataset))` is evaluated, `dataset` has already been evaluated to the full tibble structure. This happens because R evaluates function arguments in a specific order that doesn't match their declaration order.

The criterion specifically states that `name` must be evaluated early in the function using `force(name)` or a similar approach. This forces evaluation of the expression before it's too late.

Neither of the proposed solutions uses `force(name)`. Instead, they:

1. Capture the unevaluated expression with `dataset_expr <- substitute(dataset)`
2. Then conditionally set `name` based on whether it's NULL or missing

While the approaches do capture the expression before evaluation, they don't address the specific requirement of forcing early evaluation of the `name` parameter itself.

The correct approach would be to either:
1. Force evaluation of `name` at the beginning of the function
2. Or restructure the default to not depend on `dataset` after it's been evaluated

The submission is approaching the problem from a reasonable angle, but it doesn't meet the specific criterion of using `force(name)` or ensuring that `name` is evaluated early in the function.

GRADE: I

model_graded_qa(partial_credit = TRUE).explanation:
I'll assess whether the submission meets the criterion regarding the namespace issue in Shiny modules.

The criterion states that the main issue is using `NS(id)` inside a module server function instead of `session$ns`, as `NS(id)` creates a new namespace function that doesn't maintain the correct hierarchical relationship with parent modules.

Looking at the submission, it correctly identifies this key issue and provides the proper fix:

1. The submission correctly explains that the problem is related to namespace handling in nested modules.

2. It identifies the specific fix needed, changing from using `NS(id)` to `session$ns` within the `innerServer` function's `renderUI` block:
```r
output$theGeneratedUI <- renderUI({
  ns <- session$ns  # Use session$ns for proper namespacing
  tagList(
    h5("Inside theGeneratedUI"),
    verbatimTextOutput(ns("someTextGenerated")),
    plotOutput(ns("theChart"))
  )
})
```

3. The submission also fixes the other namespace issue in the `outerServer` function by using `session$ns` when calling the inner modules.

The solution directly addresses the criterion, showing a clear understanding that `session$ns` maintains the correct hierarchical relationship between modules while `NS(id)` creates a new namespace function that breaks this relationship.

GRADE: C

samples.input:
I have an R package that depends on a package called, lets say, spatialstuff (This is how it is defined in its DESCRIPTIONS). However it is found in an org and the repo name is different, eg org/spatial-Stuff (i have no control over this name!).

My package in its `DESCRIPTION` file has the following lines

```
Imports:
 spatialstuff
Remotes:
 org/spatial-Stuff
```

However the `pkgdown.yaml` workflow that is run upon pushes (created from `usethis::use_pkgdown_github_pages()`) errors with the following message.

Can someone explain if this is user error or some other error? Thanks

```
! error in pak subprocess
Caused by error:
! Could not solve package dependencies:
deps::.: Can't install dependency spatialstuff
* spatialstuff: Can't find package called spatialstuff.
* local::.: Can't install dependency spatialstuff
* any::sessioninfo: dependency conflict
* any::pkgdown: dependency conflict
```
samples.target: The user needs to specify the package name explicitly in the Remotes `DESCRIPTION` field using a `<package>=` prefix, e.g. `spatialstuff=org/spatial-Stuff`.

content.text:
# Analysis of Package Dependency Error

It appears you're encountering an issue with the package dependency resolution in your GitHub Actions workflow for pkgdown. The problem is related to how GitHub repositories with non-standard naming are referenced in R package dependencies.

## The Issue

The error occurs because:

1. Your package depends on `spatialstuff` (as defined in the DESCRIPTION)
2. The actual repository is at `org/spatial-Stuff`
3. The package installer (pak) can't establish that these are the same package

## Solution

When the package name in the DESCRIPTION doesn't match the repository name, you need to explicitly connect them. Here are two approaches:

### Option 1: Use the `package` parameter in Remotes

```
Remotes:
  org/spatial-Stuff@*release, package=spatialstuff
```

This syntax tells R that the package named `spatialstuff` should be installed from the repository `org/spatial-Stuff`.

### Option 2: Use a more explicit URL-based reference

```
Remotes:
  spatialstuff=https://github.com/org/spatial-Stuff
```

This directly maps the package name to the full repository URL.

## Additional Considerations

1. **Case sensitivity**: GitHub repos are case-sensitive, so ensure the case in your Remotes specification matches exactly.

2. **Special characters**: The hyphen in `spatial-Stuff` is likely part of the problem, as R package names conventionally avoid hyphens.

3. **GitHub Actions environment**: In your workflow file, you might need to ensure that the proper authentication and Git configurations are in place.

This appears to be a common issue when package names differ from repository names, rather than a user error on your part.

However the `pkgdown.yaml` workflow that is run upon pushes (created from `usethis::use_pkgdown_github_pages()`) errors with the following message.

```

Caused by error:
```

content.text:
# Analysis of Package Dependency Error

It appears you're encountering an issue with the package dependency resolution in your GitHub Actions workflow for pkgdown. The problem is related to how GitHub repositories with non-standard naming are referenced in R package dependencies.

## The Issue

The error occurs because:

1. Your package depends on `spatialstuff` (as defined in the DESCRIPTION)
2. The actual repository is at `org/spatial-Stuff`
3. The package installer (pak) can't establish that these are the same package

## Solution

When the package name in the DESCRIPTION doesn't match the repository name, you need to explicitly connect them. Here are two approaches:

### Option 1: Use the `package` parameter in Remotes

```
Remotes:
  org/spatial-Stuff@*release, package=spatialstuff
```

This syntax tells R that the package named `spatialstuff` should be installed from the repository `org/spatial-Stuff`.

### Option 2: Use a more explicit URL-based reference

```
Remotes:
  spatialstuff=https://github.com/org/spatial-Stuff
```

This directly maps the package name to the full repository URL.

## Additional Considerations

1. **Case sensitivity**: GitHub repos are case-sensitive, so ensure the case in your Remotes specification matches exactly.

2. **Special characters**: The hyphen in `spatial-Stuff` is likely part of the problem, as R package names conventionally avoid hyphens.

3. **GitHub Actions environment**: In your workflow file, you might need to ensure that the proper authentication and Git configurations are in place.

This appears to be a common issue when package names differ from repository names, rather than a user error on your part.

```
  }
}
```

messages.content:
I see:

```
Error:
! promise already under evaluation: recursive default argument reference or earlier problems?
```

When evaluating the function returned by this function:

```
generate <- function(chat = ellmer::chat_claude()) {
  
  function(input, chat = chat) {
    ch <- chat$clone()
    res <- ch$chat(input)
    list(result = res, chat = ch)
  }
}
```

How can I fix it?

content.text:
It looks like you're encountering a recursive default argument reference issue in your `generate()` function. The problem happens because you're using the default value of `chat` in the inner function while it's still being evaluated in the outer function.

Here's how to fix it:

```r
generate <- function(chat_instance = ellmer::chat_claude()) {
  
  function(input, chat = chat_instance) {
    ch <- chat$clone()
    res <- ch$chat(input)
    list(result = res, chat = ch)
  }
}
```

The key changes:

1. I renamed the outer parameter to `chat_instance` to avoid name collision
2. The inner function now references `chat_instance` as its default value

This solves the problem because:
- The outer parameter is fully evaluated before it's used in the inner function
- Using different parameter names prevents R from confusing which `chat` is being referenced
- The inner function's default now points to the already-evaluated value from the outer function

This way, the default argument is no longer recursively referencing itself during evaluation.

content.text:
It looks like you're encountering a recursive default argument reference issue in your `generate()` function. The problem happens because you're using the default value of `chat` in the inner function while it's still being evaluated in the outer function.

Here's how to fix it:

```r
generate <- function(chat_instance = ellmer::chat_claude()) {
  
  function(input, chat = chat_instance) {
    ch <- chat$clone()
    res <- ch$chat(input)
    list(result = res, chat = ch)
  }
}
```

The key changes:

1. I renamed the outer parameter to `chat_instance` to avoid name collision
2. The inner function now references `chat_instance` as its default value

This solves the problem because:
- The outer parameter is fully evaluated before it's used in the inner function
- Using different parameter names prevents R from confusing which `chat` is being referenced
- The inner function's default now points to the already-evaluated value from the outer function

This way, the default argument is no longer recursively referencing itself during evaluation.

samples.input:
I see this warning and error when I launch my shiny app:

```
Listening on http://127.0.0.1:3516
Warning: Error in $: Can't read output 'plot'
  46: <Anonymous>
  45: signalCondition
  44: signal_abort
  43: rlang::abort
  42: $.shinyoutput
  40: server [#2]
   3: runApp
   2: print.shiny.appobj
   1: <Anonymous>
Error in output$plot : Can't read output 'plot'
```

Here's the app's code:

```
# Load necessary libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(shiny)
library(dplyr)
library(readxl)
library(stringr)

# Load & Rename data 
Kidney_Correlations_Data <- read_excel("Kidney Correlations Data.xlsx")
Kidney_Correlations_Data <- as.data.frame(Kidney_Correlations_Data) %>%
  mutate(
    CKD_STAGE = str_replace(Kidney_Correlations_Data[[3]], "CKD 3.*", "CKD 3")
  )

# Create a reactive function to filter the data based on user input
ckd_condition <- reactive({
  input$condition
})

visit_threshold <- reactive({
  input$visit_threshold
})

filtered_data <- reactive({
  Kidney_Correlations_Data %>% 
    filter(CKD_STAGE == ckd_condition, VISIT_COUNT > visit_threshold)
})

# Create a linear model and visualization
output$plot <- renderPlot({
  validate(
    need(input$condition != "", "Please select a condition"),
    need(input$visit_threshold > 0, "Please enter a valid visit threshold")
  )
                                 # Filter the data based on the user's input
  data <- filtered_data()
  
                                 # Create a linear model
  lm_model <- lm(Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED ~ VISIT_COUNT, data = data)
  
                                 # Create a plot of the linear model
  ggplot(data, aes(x = VISIT_COUNT, y = Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED)) + 
    geom_point() + 
    geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) + 
    labs(x = "Visit Count", y = "Paid Amount")
})

# Create a dropdown menu for the user to select the CKD condition level
# and a numeric input field for the visit threshold
ui <- fluidPage(
  sidebarLayout(
    sidebarPanel(
      selectInput("condition", "Select CKD Condition:", c("CKD 3", "CKD 4", "CKD 5", "ESRD")),
      numericInput("visit_threshold", "Minimum Visit Count:", value = 5, min = 0)
    ),
    mainPanel(
      plotOutput("plot")
    )
  )
)

# Run the application
shinyApp(ui = ui, server = function(input, output) {
  output$plot
})
```

How do I fix it?
samples.target:
There's a `output$plot` alone in the anonymous server function. The solution is to move the `output$plot` and rendering code into a proper server function, like:

```
# ...same ui

server <- function(input, output) {
  # Create reactive functions to filter the data based on user input
  filtered_data <- reactive({
    Kidney_Correlations_Data %>% 
      filter(CKD_STAGE == input$condition, VISIT_COUNT > input$visit_threshold)
  })
  
  # Create a linear model and visualization
  output$plot <- renderPlot({
    validate(
      need(input$condition != "", "Please select a condition"),
      need(input$visit_threshold > 0, "Please enter a valid visit threshold")
    )
                                   # Filter the data based on the user's input
    data <- filtered_data()
    
                                   # Create a linear model
    lm_model <- lm(Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED ~ VISIT_COUNT, data = data)
    
                                   # Create a plot of the linear model
    ggplot(data, aes(x = VISIT_COUNT, y = Sum_Sum_MR_ALLOWED)) + 
      geom_point() + 
      geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) + 
      labs(x = "Visit Count", y = "Paid Amount")
  })
}

# Run the application
shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)
```

Here's the app's code:

```
# Load necessary libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(shiny)
library(dplyr)
library(readxl)
library(stringr)

# Load & Rename data 
Kidney_Correlations_Data <- read_excel("Kidney Correlations Data.xlsx")
Kidney_Correlations_Data <- as.data.frame(Kidney_Correlations_Data) %>%
  mutate(
    CKD_STAGE = str_replace(Kidney_Correlations_Data[[3]], "CKD 3.*", "CKD 3")
  )

# Create a reactive function to filter the data based on user input
ckd_condition <- reactive({

                                 # Create a linear model

                                 # Create a plot of the linear model

    geom_point() +

})

# Create a dropdown menu for the user to select the CKD condition level

  sidebarLayout(
    sidebarPanel(

# Run the application
```
